newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: De Silguy rules out creative accounting for EMU.
newsitem.headline: De Silguy rules out creative accounting for EMU.

text.p: EU Commissioner Yves-Thibault de Silguy said countries could not use creative accounting to qualify for Europe's single currency, but he declined to comment specifically on Germany's gold revaluation plan.
"I have not received details on this project from German authorities so I cannot react precisely," he told reporters.

"For countries particpating in the euro, the most important thing is to achieve a sustainable level of convergence. Accounting measures must be complemented with structural measures to achieve sound finances in the long term, but creative accounting is out of the question," he added.

"There are precise regulations known by everyone," de Silguy said. "They will be applied. There is no question of doing creative accounting. We will apply the same accountability rules to all member states without discrimination."

German Finance Minister Theo Waigel has proposed using a revaluation of the Bundesbank's gold reserves to plug a hole in the 1997 budget, triggering a wave of criticism across the EU that Bonn was resorting to creative accounting.
In Brussels, a senior EU official said the EU was unlikely to let Germany use the plan to reduce its budget deficit, but may let Bonn apply revaluation profits against outstanding debt.
